and the ingredients

So there's always, it

since, Diana, you

that the title of this

136.76.text:
The main title of the
book,"The Heart of the Plate,"

143.86.text:
It doesn't say how

146.16.text:
You'll notice it just says

148.33.text:
And in fact, it's both a
question and an answer.

155.78.text:
But at this point I'm
thinking threefold.

157.64.text:
First of all, it reflects
the most literal fact that

160.97.text:
to eat a certain way based
on plant foods taking up

165.29.text:
most of your plate
is heart healthy.

167.03.text: So there's the heart part of it.

170.04.text:
And then there was
a very personal memo

172.36.text:
I got from my editor on this

175.80.text:
into it when we finished our

178.71.text:
might be, she said,

181.54.text:

186.62.text:
And then I'm sitting there

189.95.text:
And it evolved into

196.33.text:
And then there's
also the plate itself

198.24.text:
and what is at the
heart of your plate?

199.89.text:
What is at the
center of your plate?

201.39.text:
And that is where it

205.53.text:
What is the model
that we've grown up,

207.54.text:
the model that lets
us know we've eaten?

209.63.text:
There are so many
psychological associations

211.99.text:
with what it means to
have a plate of food that

215.08.text:
It's not just eating cerebrally,
what I think I should eat,

218.90.text:
or eating centrally,
what I'm hungry for.

221.11.text:
It's also what you're
hungry for emotionally,

223.15.text:
the plate of your childhood,
which for many of us

225.59.text:
has a big hunk of

227.77.text:
And if vegetables
appear there, they're

229.39.text:
mostly decorative or a

234.18.text:
But the main thing is the hunk

237.87.text:
I both question
that in this book

242.02.text:
for your plate, which we'll
talk about in a minute.

244.27.text:
The secondary title is also
a series of semantic queries

251.44.text:
and challenges-- "Vegetarian
Recipes for a New Generation."

255.89.text:
I use the word vegetarian
pretty much for the first time

258.46.text: on the cover of any of my books.

261.01.text:
It's not a word I
like, and for me,

264.67.text:
the interpretation of
that word is not simple.

271.83.text:
I am not somebody who's
against eating meat.

274.38.text:
In fact, I like a little
bit of meat once in a while.

277.04.text:
And so here I am talking
about a vegetarian book,

279.63.text:
and we go right to
the subject of meat.

282.17.text:
In fact, for the most part,
if you think about it,

284.61.text:
when people talk about
vegetarian-- when someone

286.68.text:
sits down at your
table and says,

288.38.text:
I'm a vegetarian--
what they're mainly

290.87.text:
doing is making a
statement about meat,

293.73.text:
as in, I don't want any; as
in, keep it off my plate.

298.04.text:
In the 40 years in which
I've been writing cookbooks,

300.73.text:
I have found that almost always
the word vegetarian is that.

304.52.text:
It's about meat,
as in keep it away.

307.31.text:
And also, I have found so many
self-described vegetarians

311.23.text:
for whom it has nothing or very
little to do with vegetables.

316.52.text:
So it's not as
though someone says,

318.57.text:
I would like to stop
eating meat and therefore I

321.43.text:
am madly interested
in Brussels sprouts.

324.05.text:
The stopping eating meat for
whatever reasons, whether it's

326.51.text:
ethical or environmental or
some combination or aesthetic,

330.51.text:
very often has nothing
to do with whether or not

332.51.text:
you're going to be chowing
down on kale salads,

335.29.text:
which, by the way,
I think were just

336.79.text: invented in the last two years.

344.34.text:
So I use the word
vegetarian in the subtitle,

348.63.text:
in the secondary title,
because I personally

352.18.text:
My definition of vegetarian
has nothing to do with meat

356.11.text:
except for the fact that in
my perfect world, by the time

359.46.text:
we're all done putting
as much beautiful plant

362.78.text:
food on this reconfigured
plate as we want,

367.14.text:
there isn't much room
for anything else.

369.31.text:
If there's room, is an
incidental topping, which

372.64.text:
could be egg noodles,
which is, in my book,

376.76.text:
a thin omelette
sliced into strips

378.96.text:
so that it looks like
noodles, but it's really egg.

381.32.text:
Same thing with
tofu-- tofu noodles.

383.52.text:
If somebody wants a little bit
of meat but mostly vegetables,

386.52.text:
it could be a few strips
of last night's steak,

391.59.text:
But it's not a statement
about meat, really.

393.50.text:
It's a state about what
is the whole plate.

394.98.text:
And the plate is
filled with plant food.

396.79.text:
So this leads me to my
new vegetarian definition,

400.03.text:
which I hope you'll
agree with and adopt,

402.59.text:
which is I want vegetarian
to become in our vernacular

407.56.text:
an adjective that describes
the food on the plate

411.18.text:
and not a noun that identifies

417.96.text:
Once we do that, once we
take the word vegetarian

421.17.text:
and describe the
food with it instead

423.22.text:
of IDing the person with it,
it becomes incredibly flexible.

426.95.text:
And it becomes, I
hope, a big tent

429.42.text:
where everybody feels like they

432.00.text: and eat the same basic meal.

433.79.text:
Whether they're adding

this is a table where somebody

441.79.text:
meaning, as you all probably

444.83.text:
whatsoever, no

463.49.text:
the vegan can sit down at the

who might have had steak

it's so simple this

if just a splash

The old days, I thought

631.32.text:
romantic-- bear with-- the idea

that we can all learn new

we could be opened up to

647.15.text:
If I have two goals-- and
I like to narrow it down.

654.33.text:
OK, three-- neither
one of them has

656.02.text:
to do with getting

659.00.text:
although that is

671.39.text:
Cooking at home is a wonderful

675.82.text:
cooking where we live,

And that's a skill that needs

681.09.text: So I'm part of that squad.

And then the third goal
is-- and this is perfect

685.84.text:
because you're divided it

688.60.text:
so you can be the visual--
we have in our culture

693.30.text: a sense of dichotomy about food.

696.30.text:
So here's the

698.30.text:
And on one side is food that's

703.34.text:
that we know we're

714.09.text:
when you go to a

717.16.text:
big ones, really raw, like never

729.85.text:
But if it's the undercooked,

736.60.text:
And you will be

but the paradox is you'll

743.13.text: But you won't really want to.

746.41.text:

749.78.text:
But the dichotomy

751.24.text:
is food that's delicious

754.15.text: And we want it, and we love it.

755.87.text:
But we'll pay later
because it will

757.33.text: be unhealthy or bad for us.

759.60.text:
And the adjectives that

763.03.text:
use a lot for this is

766.81.text:
You've seen those in the

769.60.text:

773.97.text:
of us with six forks,
and everyone's going,

780.95.text:
But we're going to

but we're going to

788.20.text:
So we straddle this division,

But long way of saying one

796.25.text:
is to get rid of that division

800.27.text:
No aisle, except for fire

803.74.text:
and understand that food
that is good for you

808.74.text:
and food that is delicious
can be a one and the same.

812.03.text:
Good for you, good

814.24.text:

and all the food
can be delicious.

818.03.text: And that's one of my goals.

819.78.text:
One of the things that's
made it so much easier

826.57.text:
is that ingredients have

830.10.text:
Putting this into a cultural
and historical context,

833.80.text:
40 years ago, when I
started writing cookbooks,

836.99.text:
you could not find a bottle

841.09.text:
in this country in

843.25.text:
You could barely find

846.04.text:
Bell peppers, for example,

850.97.text:
Red bell peppers did

855.56.text:
If you found one,

857.27.text:
and you would have
to call somebody

859.38.text:
when you found a
good red pepper,

860.75.text:
and you'd want to use it

863.82.text:
Things we're so much
more limited then.

866.60.text:
And also-- and this
is a mixed blessing

868.65.text:
because I'm nostalgic
for this-- the fact

873.09.text:
that food really was local
and seasonal because that

879.55.text:
Until very recently, it

884.29.text:
or to be seasonal, which

887.37.text:
But it used to be
what there was.

889.30.text:
Local food was the
food that grew near you

891.14.text: that you would get in season.

892.70.text:
I'm from upstate
New York originally.

894.59.text:
I now live in the
East Bay, which

896.92.text:
is so heavenly in

899.95.text:
my East Coast friends

901.61.text:
because I just put
in a bed of lettuce,

905.61.text: We're very blessed to live here.

907.45.text:
When I first moved to the
Bay Area, the very first time

910.63.text:
in the early '70s, when
I was writing recipes,

913.92.text:
I would have to call my mother,

917.06.text:
in the middle of winter to

922.80.text:
I didn't want to
write recipes only

924.26.text:
for people who lived
in the Bay Area,

although that would've

928.67.text:
So the idea that we can

931.58.text:
most of the time is a

936.97.text:

940.20.text: produce a good deal of the time.

There are grains and legumes and

946.36.text:

951.96.text:

So all this good

967.04.text: makes it so easy to cook simply.

My idea now of a really

974.74.text:
on the plate in some kind

977.32.text:
rather than throwing

2290.04.text:
But olive oil, a
lot of that, do you

2294.05.text:
have any insights as to whether
there is good research about--?

2298.04.text:
MOLLIE KATZEN: I
have to qualify first

2299.62.text:
by saying I am not a
nutrition researcher nor am

2301.81.text:
I a dietitian, so I just pilfer
information from those who are.

2308.96.text:
It's my understanding that
oil is very heart healthy,

2312.40.text:
that olive oil, that you
should go out of your way

2315.56.text:
to include it in your diet
because it is, in fact, a heart

2320.99.text:
And nuts also-- not even just
nut oils but nuts, avocados,

2325.64.text:
those kinds of oils are
very, very healthful.

2329.03.text:
And I believe-- and I
will check with him--

2331.79.text:
but I am pretty sure that Dr.
Walter Willett of the Harvard

2334.27.text:
School of Public Health, who
is the head of their nutrition

2336.73.text:
department, is up to a
good probably 30% or more

2341.04.text:
of the calories per
day that he would

2342.63.text:
like you to get from
olive oil alone.

2345.84.text:
The model is called
The Mediterranean Diet,

2349.34.text: and it also includes fatty fish.

2352.17.text:
It also includes one or two
drinks a day of alcohol.

2356.83.text:
So for people who like
alcohol, that's a nice thing.

2359.29.text:
So for the people I know
and the people who school me

2362.76.text:
in these things, I
would say that I'm

2364.58.text:
very pro healthy oil
but anti unhealthy oil.

2370.10.text:
But it's a question of
the quality of the oil.

2373.77.text:
It's not all fat is bad,
but look for the good oils.

2377.35.text:
In fact, it really
makes no sense

2379.08.text:
according to these researchers--
and I am totally convinced

2381.80.text:
by them-- to, when you
see those labels on food

2385.02.text:
and they tell you
calories from oil,

2387.79.text:
percentage oil, grams
of fat-- meaningless.

2394.78.text: What do you take home from that?

2397.22.text:
It's all about quantities of
fat, which don't mean anything.

2400.40.text:
It's not a different
kind of calorie.

2403.44.text:
It's not necessarily
bad or good.

2405.65.text:
You have to look
further and see what

2408.38.text: is the actual source of fat.

But it is my understanding
that a good oil

2415.55.text:
The expression, the phrase,

2421.02.text:
Those are fatty acids

2424.98.text: So you need to take it in.

Contact with the surface,

is in itself a way of

2493.32.text:
on its proximity to the heat

and the kind of oil,

you hearing the

2517.75.text:

MOLLIE KATZEN: But it is

2532.98.text:
I love cast iron, and it's

And for me, it's

2537.11.text:
inducing because the
first cookware I ever

2542.05.text: And it's a very honest cookware.

2544.45.text:
And I like the fact you can

2548.26.text:
I'd much rather
have a pan that's

2549.63.text:
been heated on a medium-low
flame for a longer

2552.11.text:
period of time than flashing
something with a sudden burst.

2556.39.text:
So I would go with
something-- anodized

2559.40.text:
steel is a really nice,
heavy kind of cookware which

2564.75.text:
I like a lot and
then the cast iron.

2566.33.text:
But avoid anything
that's very lightweight--

2569.41.text:
literally lightweight--
and that is coated.

2573.59.text:
One way you can have a non-stick
situation without it being

2579.49.text:
patient with the
heating of the pan

2581.70.text:
and make sure it gets very,
very hot and then add your oil.

2586.15.text:
And then make sure the
oil itself gets very hot

2589.82.text:
so that when the food finally

2593.56.text:
Again, hearing the

2595.03.text:
that it's probably

2596.65.text:
And then you have
a metal spatula

2598.80.text:
with which you scrape

2600.73.text:
And you shake it, keep it

Your cooking habit becomes

My recipes used to say, oh,

I don't even

And we expect them to

they get very upset and want

2765.78.text:
And it's a wonderful

a child's feeling

2833.78.text:
